bestBHT.bht: The bitter enemies of Jesus, the official body of the Jews, could not deny the reality and the irresistible effect of His miracles. Fearing a revolution due to the popular enthusiasm, they planned to bring Him down. Fully aware of the danger, Jesus retreated to the wilderness, the wild hill-country northeast of Jerusalem, where He could momentarily escape the machinations of the Sanhedrin. By seeking refuge in Ephraim, Jesus displayed wisdom in preserving His life until the appointed hour of His sacrifice at the Passover.

Henry Alford: Observe the word Jews here, used as designating the official body.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: While we trifle, 'this man,' by His 'many miracles,' will carry all before Him; the popular enthusiasm will bring on a revolution...
What a testimony to the reality of our Lord's miracles, and their resistless effect, from His bitterest enemies!
The reality of our Lord's miracles and their resistless effect.
Albert Barnes: Jesus never exposed his life unnecessarily to hazard.
Although the time of his death was determined in the counsel of God, yet this did not prevent his using proper means to preserve his life.
This was probably a small town in the tribe of Ephraim, about five miles west of Jericho.
Marvin Vincent: Wilderness. The wild hill - country, northeast of Jerusalem.

Ephraim. The site is uncertain. Commonly taken as Ophrah (1 Samuel 13:17), or Ephraim (2 Chronicles 13:19), and identified with el - Taiyibeh, sixteen miles from Jerusalem, and situated on a hill which commands the Jordan valley.
John Calvin: For we know how greatly the language was changed after the captivity into Babylon, and likewise how different was the appearance of the country; so that we need not be surprised that some places are mentioned, which in ancient times were altogether unknown."
By calling them disciples of Christ, he means not those who had received his doctrine, but those who were his constant companions, and who were wont to live under the same roof.
Philip Schaff: The time of ‘free speech’ was at an end: from this time Jesus avoided communication with ‘the Jews,’ no longer vouchsafing to them the word which they heard only to reject.
The crisis in His life is graver; the retirement which he seeks is more profound.
The wilderness will be ‘the wild uncultivated hill country north-east of Jerusalem, lying between the central towns and the Jordan valley.'
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus saw clearly that to do so would bring on the end now instead of his 'hour' which was to be at the passover a month ahead.
Up here Jesus would at least be free for the moment from the machinations of the Sanhedrin while he faced the coming catastrophe at the passover.

Is it mere fancy to imagine that the devil came to see Jesus again here at this juncture with a reminder of his previous offer and of the present plight of the Son of God with the religious leaders conspiring his death?
John Gill: Jesus...walked no more openly among the Jews."
And there continued with his disciples

bhtAttempts.bht: After witnessing the powerful miracles of Jesus, even His bitterest enemies, the official body of the Jews, acknowledged the irresistible effect of His works. Recognizing that further delay would only intensify the popular enthusiasm that jeopardized their authority, they plotted to put an end to Him. Jesus, fully aware of the impending danger, withdrew to the wilderness, the wild hill-country northeast of Jerusalem, seeking temporary respite and safety until His appointed hour at the Passover. During this time, Jesus possibly faced the devil's reminder of previous offers and contemplated His present plight. By retreating to Ephraim, identified as either Ophrah or Ephraim and located on a hill commanding the Jordan Valley, Jesus sought respite from the machinations of the Sanhedrin while preparing for the coming catastrophe at the Passover. In this crucial moment, Jesus avoided further contact with the Jews, no longer willing to communicate with them, as the time of free speech had ended. By His actions, Jesus displayed prudence in preserving His life, even as the time of His death approached, fulfilling the divine plan.

In acknowledging the undeniable power of Jesus' miracles, even His bitter enemies, the official body of the Jews, recognized their sway over the people. Fearing a revolution spurred by the popular enthusiasm, they determined to eliminate Him. Jesus, fully aware of the imminent danger, withdrew to the wilderness, seeking temporary respite and safety until His appointed hour. By retreating to Ephraim, Jesus found relief from the plots of the Sanhedrin, while preparing for the impending tragedy at the Passover. Jesus exercised prudence in preserving His life, despite the divine plan for His death.

Jesus' powerful miracles left even His bitter enemies, the official body of the Jews, acknowledging their undeniable impact. Fearful that the popular enthusiasm would lead to a revolt, they sought to bring an end to Him. Sensing the impending danger, Jesus withdrew to the wilderness, a wild hill-country northeast of Jerusalem. By retreating to Ephraim, a town in the tribe of Ephraim, Jesus found a momentary escape from the Sanhedrin's schemes, and prepared Himself for the impending tragedy at the Passover. Jesus exercised caution in preserving His life while fulfilling His divine destiny.

The bitter enemies of Jesus, the official body of the Jews, could not deny the reality and the irresistible effect of His miracles. Fearing a revolution due to the popular enthusiasm, they planned to bring Him down. Fully aware of the danger, Jesus retreated to the wilderness, the wild hill-country northeast of Jerusalem, where He could momentarily escape the machinations of the Sanhedrin. By seeking refuge in Ephraim, Jesus displayed wisdom in preserving His life until the appointed hour of His sacrifice at the Passover.

Recognizing the undeniable impact of Jesus' miracles, even His enemies, the official body of the Jews, felt compelled to acknowledge their reality and power. Fearing the potential revolution spurred by the popular enthusiasm, they sought to bring an end to Him. Fully aware of the imminent danger, Jesus withdrew to the wilderness, the wild hill-country northeast of Jerusalem. By retreating to Ephraim, Jesus sought temporary respite from the Sanhedrin's plots, while preparing Himself for the impending catastrophe at the Passover. In this pivotal moment, Jesus exercised caution in preserving His life while fulfilling His divine mission.
